p: The antisteatotic effects of C. longa were investigated in rodent models induced by CCl 4 [ 13, 14, 21, 23], high-fructose diet [ 54, 55], and high-fat diet [ 54, 56, 57]. C. longa decreased the levels of TG contents, total cholesterol, and low-density lipoprotein (LDL) in the liver tissue, and hepatic histological findings by Oil Red O staining were consistently improved. Regarding the antisteatotic effects of C. longa, its water extract at 250°C impeded the uptake of fatty acids into the liver by suppressing the mRNA expression of CD36 and fatty acid transport protein (FATP) in C57BL/6 mice. In addition, it inhibited intrahepatic lipid synthesis via the regulation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein-1c (SREBP-1c), fatty acid synthase (FAS), and acetyl CoA carboxylase-1 (ACC) mRNA levels. Furthermore, it promoted lipolysis partially through the regulation of AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK), peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor- α (PPAR- α), and carnitine palmitoyltransferase-1 (CPT-1) mRNA levels [ 56]. Particularly, the rhizomes of C. longa facilitated the secretion of lipids from the liver into blood via the increase in hepatic PDI [ 13] and betaine [ 54] expression in male SD rats.
